spanishExample: ¿Quién estaba aquí hasta ese día?
englishTranslation: Who was here until that day?

spanishExample: ¿Quién estará aquí hasta que nos vayamos?
englishTranslation: Who will be here until we leave?
vocabIncluded: estará: "will be", "he/she/it will be" (Estar, future, 3rd person)
irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"

spanishExample: Ella *wished* que yo estuviera con ellos.
englishTranslation: She wished I was with them(m).
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Estarán aquí hasta que nos vayamos.
englishTranslation: They’ll be here until we leave.
vocabIncluded: irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"

spanishExample: Fueron amigos por unos años.
englishTranslation: They were friends for a few years.

spanishExample: Fui el *captain* de ese *game.*
englishTranslation: I was the captain(m) of that game(m).

spanishExample: Fuiste el que estaba ahí ese día.
englishTranslation: You were the one(m) who was there that day.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener

spanishExample: Hay tres chicas de más aquí.
englishTranslation: There are three extra girls here.
vocabIncluded: hay: "there is/are" indicating existence (Haber, present, impersonal)

spanishExample: *He wanted* que yo fuera su amigo y que tuviera tiempo para él.
englishTranslation: He wanted me to be his friend and to have time for him.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: No está de más tener hasta uno más.
englishTranslation: It couldn’t hurt to have even one more.
vocabIncluded: no está de más: "it couldn't hurt" (idiom)

spanishExample: No fue ni *a mistake* ni *an accident* para nada.
englishTranslation: It wasn’t either a mistake or an accident at all.

spanishExample: No fuimos ni *the winners* ni *the losers.*
englishTranslation: We weren’t either the winners or the losers.

spanishExample: No me voy, en vez de eso, estaré aquí hasta que te vayas.
englishTranslation: I’m not leaving; instead of that, I’ll be here until you leave.
vocabIncluded: estaré: "will be", "I will be" (Estar, future, 1st person)
irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"

spanishExample: No *she moves* hasta que le *I tell* esto.
englishTranslation: She doesn’t move until I tell her this.
vocabIncluded: le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: *She wanted* que fuera con ella.
englishTranslation: She wanted me to go with her.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Si ella también fuera tu amiga, sería bueno.
englishTranslation: If she also were your friend, it would be good.
vocabIncluded: sería: "would be", "he/she/it would be" (Ser, conditional, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Si ella también fuera, sería *a problem* porque *it’s late.*
englishTranslation: If she also went, it would be a problem because it’s late.
vocabIncluded: sería: "would be", "he/she/it would be" (Ser, conditional, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Si estuviera en casa, lo tendría.
englishTranslation: If I were at home, I would have it.
vocabIncluded: tendría: "would have", "I would have" (Tener, conditional, 1st person)

spanishExample: Si tuviera hasta uno más, sería mejor.
englishTranslation: If I had even one more, it would be better.
vocabIncluded: sería: "would be", "he/she/it would be" (Ser, conditional, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Tengo que *call* a mi amigo porque tiene de todo en su casa.
englishTranslation: I have to call my friend because he has a bit of everything in his house.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
"the personal a": using an extra "a" before a direct object when it's a person
tiene de todo: "has some of everything" (idiom)
